Award.AwardTitle: U.S. Participation in the ICM Operator Algebras Satellite Conference
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for US participation in the conference "ICM Satellite Operator Algebras Conference" that will be held July 26-30, 2018, at the Universidade Federal de Santa Catarina in Florianopolis, Brazil.

The conference focuses on recent developments in Analysis, especially in the field of operator theory. A number of distinguished mathematicians have agreed to attend and speak at this conference. This award gives early career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, researchers not funded by NSF and the like an opportunity to attend and participate in this conference. The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities. More information will be made available at: http://mtm.ufsc.br/icmoa/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Congress of Mathematicians (ICM) is the most prestigious conference in the discipline, only occuring every four years and the venue for awarding the Fields Medal, the highest honor in mathematics. Affiliated with this conference are dozens of satellite events, typically research conferences focusing on a specific subfield of mathematics. These satellite events attract leading researchers, from early-career to senior ranks, for focused presentations of the most important work being done around the world. They are also an extraordinary opportunity for dissemination of one's own work, as well as laying the groundwork for collaborations with international colleagues. This award supported participation by US-based researchers in the ICM Operator Algebras Satellite Conference, July 26-30, in Florianopolis, Santa Catarina, Brazil. Operator algebras were developed by John von Neumann as the theoretical framework for quantum mechanics about 100 years ago. From the beginning these abstract objects encoded quantum phenomena and had deep connections with physics. Since then the field has grown dramatically and now has deep connections with and applications to many areas of mathematics such as topology, geometry, measure theory, dynamical systems, geometric group theory, dimension theory, K-theory, probability and more. As such, this award supported US-based researchers' participation in an important conference that attracted top researchers from around the world. In particular, a significant portion of support went to early-career researchers, including promising graduate students, and underrepresented researchers, which represents an important investment in the human capital and diversity that will ensure US-based researchers remain leaders in the field of mathematics.
